content: SECTION 1. ADDITIONAL CERTIFICATION REGARDING DRUG-PRODUCING AND DRUG-TRANSIT COUNTRIES. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subparagraph requiring countries to cooperate with the United States or take steps to comply with the goals of the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to comply with the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances by achieving established goals and objectives, and making adequate progress towards meeting plans and timetables. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to comply with the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances by achieving established goals and objectives, and making adequate progress towards meeting plans and timetables. Additionally, amendments are made to various subsections of the Act, including inserting "or (B)" after "subparagraph (A)" in subparagraph (C) and making conforming amendments in subsections (b)(3), (c), and (f). The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to comply with the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances by achieving established goals and objectives. Additional requirements are added regarding qualified certification, including convening a high-level contact group for countries certified under subsection (b)(1)(B). Additional requirements are added for qualified certification, including convening a high-level contact group consisting of key officials from the United States and the certified country. The high-level contact group for each country should establish specific benchmarks to monitor progress under the plan, program, or timetable. The purpose of these benchmarks is to objectively verify the country's progress. These benchmarks aim to objectively verify the country's progress by setting measurable goals and deadlines related to arrests, extradition, eradication of drug-related crops, money-laundering, and other relevant matters. The high-level contact group for each country must set specific benchmarks to monitor progress, including measurable goals and deadlines related to various matters. A deadline of 60 days is set for completion of activities, and an annual benchmark report must be submitted to Congress by September 1. The President must report on the progress made by each country in meeting the benchmarks set forth, with consultation from the Attorney General.
